Award.AwardTitle: Artistic and Scientific Fieldwork at the South Pole: Inquiry at the Edge of Possibility
Award.AbstractNarration: The project will contribute to academic research into the connections between science and art with the intent to make an original contribution to the growing body of research that explores the use of scientific data in art. Specifically, the artist will use data gathered by the IceCube Neutrino Observatory to inform a range of works, including data-based sound installations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was undertaken at McMurdo Station and at the Amundsen-Scott South Pole Station between December 7th 2016 and January 9th 2017. A total of 33 days on the Ice - 18 days at Pole and 15 at McMurdo.

At McMurdo Station my primary activities were orientation and acclimation. The main research activities at McMurdo were a one day snowmobile field trip to Cape Evans to view and document the historic hut from Scott’s Terra Nova expedition and examination of several major upper atmospheric and magnetospheric detectors currently housed near McMurdo - including the historical but still active ‘CosRay’ cosmic ray detector (during its last season of active operation at McMurdo), and several experiments currently active at Arrival Heights, including the long term extremely-low-frequency and very-low-frequency (ELF/VLF) radio frequency observatory and the Super Dual Auroral RADAR Network (SuperDARN) Antenna Array.

The main focus of my research was at the Amundsen-Scott South Pole Station. Here I was imbedded with scientists operating the IceCube Neutrino Observatory (https://icecube.wisc.edu).

I had developed several sculptural instruments that I shipped to Antarctica in advance of my arrival. These were deployed at the Pole in close proximity to IceCube and on the roof of the main Amundsen-Scott base amongst other atmospheric instruments. These sculptural instruments recorded atmospheric and solar data as analog markings and sound and were documented in situ through photographs and time-lapse video. As well, in collaboration with IceCube scientists, I developed novel methods for the sonification of data from the IceCube array that effectively transformed the array into an enormous stringed instrument activated by cosmogenic subatomic particles.

The outcomes of this research will be exhibited at several venues in 2018, including the Nevada Museum of Art, in Reno, Nevada and the Australian National University in Canberra, Australia. More detailed descriptions and documentation of my activities in Antarctica can be found at http://www.donaldfortescue.com/antarctica
